author: timbeiko
content:
Just published a blog-form update on 1559 as it had been requested by a lot of folks in the community: https://hackmd.io/@timbeiko/1559-update-001

I don't think anything in it should be news to most folks here üòÖ I expect to keep publishing them every 2-3 weeks. If there's something you'd like to have included in a future update, just ping me about it

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!552133098075193354> I wonder about the value of publishing details about how to get on the implementers call in a community blog post like that.

author: sky.cactus
content: The people we *want* on the call all know how to find it, and the community should definitely have easy access to the recording.  Anyone who has legitimate feedback has lots of places they can provide it and if they have valuable feedback that is worthy of bringing up on the call I'm sure someone can/will give them details on how to get to the call.

author: butta
content:
> This indirectly impacts network value by reducing the available supply of ether.
<@!552133098075193354>  what do you mean with "network value"? Price of ETH?

author: qu0b
content: Interesting read that speaks out against burning tokens: https://www.placeholder.vc/blog/2020/9/17/stop-burning-tokens-buyback-and-make-instead

author: .vbuterin
content: So we can think about burning and market-making as two separate operations: (i) remove the tokens from supply, (ii) add tokens to the supply and put them into a market maket

author: .vbuterin
content: This is a useful mental construct because it shows that the question of "burn vs market-make" is really the question of "is issuing into a market maker better than doing nothing"? Which is in turn the question "are the benefits of market making worth the dilution?"

author: .vbuterin
content: To which the answer can only ever be "maybe"!

author: .vbuterin
content: Subsidizing market making is a public good, and as with all public goods, subdizing them is often optimal, though the optimal level is less than infinity

author: .vbuterin
content: So in the case of app tokens, this is maybe a good idea

author: .vbuterin
content: In the case of ETH, the problem is that ethereum the platform does not "trust" any asset other than ETH itself, so.... what does ETH get market-made against?

author: butta
content:
> In the case of ETH, the problem is that ethereum the platform does not "trust" any asset other than ETH itself, so.... what does ETH get market-made against?
<@!273808422753796097> I'd see the argument that ETH is market made against bitcoin; that's how it was initially launched @ presale

author: qu0b
content:
> buybacks do have a positive influence on price, but burning doesn‚Äôt create new value, it only redistributes current value among a smaller group of people. There‚Äôs a reason why companies that do a lot of buybacks are associated with low growth.
ETH can't really be marked made, with proof of stake it is moving more in the direction of a governance token rather than just being a gas mule. The slowed growth potential of burning is what worries me.

author: timbeiko
content:
> <@!552133098075193354> I wonder about the value of publishing details about how to get on the implementers call in a community blog post like that.
<@!301186049323958275> good point. I removed the link üëç

author: timbeiko
content:
> <@!552133098075193354>  what do you mean with "network value"? Price of ETH?
<@!97774605351010304> more like "market cap", but yes, that implies the price of ETH

author: butta
content: How do you prove that Eip1559 will increase the price?

author: butta
content: who am i complaining to if it goes down ü§®

author: timbeiko
content: We don't "prove" it, but EIP-1559 will decrease the supply, and the amount by which it does so is proportional to usage, given the base fee rises when blocks are full. Obviously, there are many _other_ factors that affect the price of ETH, so it's naive to think the EIP itself will cause the price to rise given that something else of a larger magnitude could affect it more.

author: butta
content: But your post doesn‚Äôt mention any of the other factors but makes it sound like that the EIP by itself will pump the price. Very misleading imo.

author: timbeiko
content:
That's fair. I tried to explain what the feedback mechanism was in detail, but perhaps I should have added an extra caveat? 

> Finally, burning the BASE FEE creates a positive feedback loop between network usage and network value. As more people want to use the network, the BASE FEE goes up, which means a larger amount of ether gets burnt in each block. This indirectly impacts network value by reducing the available supply of ether.

author: timbeiko
content:
I could add a footnote, around the lines of:
> Obviously, many other factors can affect the network value, and ETH has historically been very volatile. There is no guarantee that EIP-1559 would bring network value higher than it is today.

author: butta
content:
And that leads to my next question:

Why is that even being used as argument if it depends on X other factors to make that argument valid? 
There are many ‚ÄûIFs‚Äú and uncertainties with this EIP which i believe many are not aware of.

author: butta
content:
That‚Äôs also why i asked if you can prove it. 
I could also make the point that Eip1559 will crash Eth price.

author: timbeiko
content: I think that's a bit different though: the burn mechansim _does_ reduce supply, and price is a function of supply and demand. We obviously can't control demand, hence the uncertainty.

author: timbeiko
content: If you have a valid argument for why 1559 would negatively impact the price of ETH, then it's absolutely something we should consider as a risk and address.

author: timbeiko
content: Just added a footnote to the post making it clearer, <@!97774605351010304>

author: butta
content:
> If you have a valid argument for why 1559 would negatively impact the price of ETH, then it's absolutely something we should consider as a risk and address.
<@!552133098075193354> 

0) There might be less usage for ETH because everyone starts speculating about what could happen if the supply decreased even more! <- Yes, this would also require a few factors to line up, just like the "Moon" argument. :)

1) We expect every gateway to implement it flawlessly when for instances exchanges can barely keep up a full node without complaining. What happens if they implement it incorrectly?

2) ETHUSD went from a few dollars to $1500, that's a 30,000% increase without burning anything.
   What would have happened if EIP1559 was implemented? 

3) Miner's could push the BASEFEE to 0. "But that would be equivalent to a 51% attack." 
    No, it is not. 51% attacks are a short term gain, whereas pushing the basefee down would be a longterm gain

author: timbeiko
content:
> 1) We expect every gateway to implement it flawlessly when for instances exchanges can barely keep up a full node without complaining. What happens if they implement it incorrectly?
We're currently reaching out to exchanges/gateways to get a feel for what they need to support it. We'll share the aggregated feedback in the next couple weeks as we wrap up interviews. I believe ethernodes has submitted a response already. Also, both legacy and 1559-style txns are anticipated to be supported for a while after the launch of 1559 (how long is going to be informed by those conversations).

author: timbeiko
content:
> 2) ETHUSD went from a few dollars to $1500, that's a 30,000% increase without burning anything.
>    What would have happened if EIP1559 was implemented? 
Not sure I understand this? The rise to 1500$ was caused by more demand (ICOs, mostly). Again, 1559 affects supply.

author: timbeiko
content:
> 3) Miner's could push the BASEFEE to 0. "But that would be equivalent to a 51% attack." 
>     No, it is not. 51% attacks are a short term gain, whereas pushing the basefee down would be a longterm gain
Can you expand on how they would do that?

author: butta
content:
> Not sure I understand this? The rise to 1500$ was caused by more demand (ICOs, mostly). Again, 1559 affects supply.
<@!552133098075193354> maybe, maybe not. Pure speculation. That's why I believe eip1559 is nonsense as it doesn't guarantee anything but puts the whole network at risk

author: timbeiko
content: I mean, price aside, it does help with processing txns quicker and handling spikes in usage more rapidly. Would you be more in favor of something like 1559 that didn't burn the BASE FEE?

author: butta
content:
> it does help with processing txns quicker  
how?

author: timbeiko
content: because you always have extra room in your block, unless there's a sudden spike in demand

author: butta
content:
> something like 1559 that didn't burn the BASE FEE?
not really, i'd rather have it in ETH2.0 and bait users with that moon argument to eth2.0

author: timbeiko
content: I see a large part of the value of what we're doing now in proving out that this _can_ work for Eth2 (and Eth1 obviously)

author: timbeiko
content: Eth1 will basically be the 1559 MVP for Eth2

author: timbeiko
content: And, if the Eth2 plan still is to have and Eth1 shard as the first one, then we need 1559 in Eth1 to make that happen.

author: timbeiko
content: And we probably don't want to hard fork both from PoW to PoS *and* to 1559 at the same time üòÖ

author: butta
content: have you done the the calculations how much ETH would be burned if EIP 1559 was implemented asap for the next 3 years (assuming eth2 transition is then) ?

author: butta
content: Then I'd ask myself if burning X Eth is worth putting the network at risk; or if i would rather wait a few years

author: timbeiko
content: How would deploying this on Eth2 make things less risky, though?

author: timbeiko
content: I get the argument that doing nothing is less risky

author: butta
content: do you actually believe that burning a few M of ETH will push the price? did the parity bug pump the price? lol

author: timbeiko
content: but IMO waiting until Eth2 and deploying 1559 as part of that transition feels _way_ riskier

author: butta
content: we have ~10% of the supply in defi, but price is dropping *

author: timbeiko
content: I mean, the price has roughly tripled over the past 6 mo?

author: timbeiko
content: Again, I think it's hard to predict or make inferences on the actual price because there are a ton of factors at play, but yes, I suspect if you were to remove the 10% that's held in DeFi today, the price would drop

author: butta
content: this is literally what we are trying to do before eth2

author: timbeiko
content: So do you think we should just not have large protocol changes on Eth1 until Eth2?

author: butta
content: yep

author: timbeiko
content: i.e. Account Abstractions, Statlessness/Witnesses, etc.

author: butta
content: EIP1559 is the first EIP that actually touches the whole protocol, doesnt it ?

author: timbeiko
content: I'm not sure of the full history, but it definitely is one of the largest if not the single biggest one, yep. I think it's on par with something like adding witnesses in terms of complexity.

author: timbeiko
content: Because they change the txn format, block header, propagation, etc.

author: butta
content:
there is a difference between actual improvements and speculation, eip1559 is based on speculation. 
Unless i missed any of the proves you have linked

author: timbeiko
content: I think EIP-1559 *does* help beyond price: you get better predicability of txn fees, extra space in each block for quick inclusion and process spikes in usage quicker.

author: butta
content: https://twitter.com/realLedgerwatch/status/1306870150013095936

author: butta
content: basically this

author: qu0b
content: I really don‚Äôt see the point in leaving half the block empty and wasting resources when instead we could work on making it more efficient and increasing throughput. How is forcing a market onto a eip 1559 function more efficient?

author: djrtwo
content:
the average capacity would be the same as today (half empty/half full isn't really the point here). The max block size increases to up to 2x current size
The fee market is incredibly inefficient and a usability nightmare today.
Vitalik's FAQ is on 1559 is excellent if you haven't seen it https://notes.ethereum.org/Wjr1SnW-QaST7phX9C5wkg?view

author: djrtwo
content:
> How is forcing a market onto a eip 1559 function more efficient
I'm not sure I understand the question

author: timbeiko
content:
> when instead we could work on making it more efficient and increasing throughput.
I don't think is an either/or. We can do both, and most likely will need to in order to mitigate the potential DoS risks caused by having some blocks being 2x as large.
